story:
Short Summary

PRIMECom Corporation is a Canadian Radio-Television Telecommunication Commission (CRTC) certified production , media and advertising company based in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, Canada. We produced content for OMNI TV (a Rogers Company), Shaw Spotlights (formerly Shaw Community TV) and Filipino TV (FTV) for several years already. Our production team is composed of Filipino-Canadians who are entrepreneurs and also practicing professionals in Engineering, Health and Real Estate and Media Industry.

In our desire to create more content and fill up the time slots offered to us by our TV network affiliates, we contacted Dante Nico Garcia, a Filipino filmmaker whose first film, Ploning, became the entry the Philippines for the 81st Oscar Awards. Dante has been an advocate of films and content that promote the beauty of the Philippines and the talent of the Filipinos, waiting for the perfect partners to help him produce all the film and television show concepts he has developed through the years. We feel that this is the best time for Filipinos and people who care for the Filipinos, to come together and not only create content that entertain and educate, but also support good causes with every season produced. In line with this, Dante created FilipiNow, a portal where we feature the Filipino which presents fresh and new stories of the Filipino as they move in the here and now. This will be a good vehicle to connect with Filipinos who've never been to the Philippines, haven't seen or experienced living in the Philippines, and those who want to visit the Philippines. 

“New normal, new stories, new lives...” The way of life that the Filipinos are experiencing nowadays goes under the microscope with this unique peek into their lives. Every episode gives viewers a slice of life of the Filipinos today.

We have successfully launched our first FilipiNow episode under Pinoy Konek show last February 28, 2021 Our second episode is currently aired in Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta, Canada via OMNI TV.

What We Need & What You Get

The funds that we are raising will be used to support production of video contents and create pitch videos so that we can start selling our shows lined-up for 2021 to brands and organizations.

As our valued supporters, we offer the following perks based on the amount that you contribute.

Gold Category: CAD$ 1000 (reduced from $1500)   Qty: 3(max)

Co-Producer credit in one season of TV Series.

Producer credit in one season of a YouTube show.

Solo ‘Thank you’ post in our Facebook Page.

Greetings by one of our puppets within a YouTube Video.

Greetings by one of our puppets within a Facebook Live session.

‘Thank you’ post in our Instagram Stories

FilipiNow T-shirt

FilipiNow Coffee Mug

 

Silver Category: CAD$ 750 (reduced from $1000) Qty: 6 (max)

Co-Producer credit in one season of TV Series

Producer credit in one of our YouTube Videos.

Solo ‘Thank you’ post in our Facebook Page.

Greetings by one of our puppets within a YouTube Video.

Greetings by one of our puppets within a Facebook Live session.

‘Thank you’ post in our Instagram Stories.

FilipiNow Coffee Mug

 

Bronze Category: CAD$ 500 (reduced from $750) Qty: 12 (max)

Co-Producer credit in one episode of TV Series

Co-Producer credit in one of our YouTube Videos.

Solo ‘Thank you’ post in our Facebook Page.

Greetings by one of our puppets within a YouTube Video.

Greetings by one of our puppets within a Facebook Live session.

‘Thank you’ post in our Instagram Stories.

FilipiNow T-shirt

 

CAD$ 150

Co-Producer credit in one of our YouTube Videos.

Solo ‘Thank you’ post in our Facebook Page.

Greetings by one of our puppets within a YouTube Video.

Greetings by one of our puppets within a Facebook Live session.

‘Thank you’ post in our Instagram Stories.

CAD$ 100 

Solo ‘Thank you’ post in our Facebook Page.

Greetings by one of our puppets within a YouTube Video.

Greetings by one of our puppets within a Facebook Live session.

‘Thank you’ post in our Instagram Stories.

CAD$ 70

Greetings by one of our puppets within a YouTube Video.

Greetings by one of our puppets within a Facebook Live session.

Thank you’ post in our Facebook Page.

‘Thank you’ post in our Instagram Stories

CAD$ 30

Greetings by one of our puppets within a Facebook Live session.

Thank you’ post in our Facebook Page.

‘Thank you’ post in our Instagram Stories

CAD$ 15

‘Thank you’ post in our Facebook Page.

‘Thank you’ post in our Instagram Stories.

CAD$ 7

‘Thank you’ post in our Instagram Stories.

 

The Impact

If the FilipiNow brand of content becomes a staple in Filipino homes all over the world, parents need not worry anymore about their children losing their Filipino identity.

Risks & Challenges

The risk is more on the idea that if we don't pursue this advocacy, today's children that are born and raised away from the Philippines, and the ones quarantined indefinitely in their homes, will develop identities according to the content they consume.

How to sustain the quality of the content produced in connection to the demand to make every content relevant to every Filipino anywhere in the world will be the biggest challenge once this advocacy has started.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share the link below: 

https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/filipinow-fi...

story:
WELCOME! 

Thank you so much for taking the time to consider donating to Parked In America, a television pilot that is going into production in late October! 

This show has been in development for the past year and we can't believe it's finally time to start production. Parked In America tells the story of Jamie Park, a rebellious, family-oriented teenager who moves in with her aunt's family after tragedy strikes back home in Korea. Helmed by a talented, diverse group of NYU students, we have the opportunity to portray a story not often seen in traditional media while exploring themes such as family and personal acceptance. 

By donating to the show, you are directly assisting us in bringing this story to life. Not only are you supplementing our educational experience here at NYU, but your donations allow us to reach our fullest potential. We invite you to read a letter from our show's creator, meet the members of our team, and scroll through some of our FAQ's. We are so grateful to you for taking the time to learn more about this show - thank you, thank you, thank you. 

 

WHY WE'RE DIFFERENT / OUR IMPACT!

From Creator Kayla Lewis:

This project is heavily inspired by my personal experience as a Korean American and the experiences of my mother and grandmother as Korean immigrants. I wrote this story not only because I wanted to, but because I felt the need to share our story with the world, and to express my gratitude to these two women who continue to shape my identity and teach me what it means to be Korean. I’m the daughter of a Korean immigrant and a white midwesterner, and watching my mother interact with my father’s family has always been interesting for me to see: how they all change around each other, and the culture clashes I found between them. Growing up existing between two worlds has given me many experiences that have not yet been portrayed on screen that I feel like others who look like me can relate to. 

At NYU film, the second largest demographic is the Asian community. From all around the world, Asian cinephiles come to study here at a predominately white school in a predominately white industry. Though some grew up on international films with faces that looked like theirs, most did not. And whether or not they grew up with people who looked like them on screen, none of them represented the kind of lives and stories we are living now. And that’s why we’re here: to share the stories we live now so that more people like us can see more people like us on screen.

Coming off of recent successes in the box office, it’s clear that representation matters and people need to see themselves on the big screen. However, Asian stories are still some of the least represented in the media. With this project, my hope is to tell an authentic story that can reach all audiences, Asian American or otherwise. 

Most importantly, this series is about embracing differences. In this divisive time in our history, I think we all need a reminder that we are one, big, dysfunctional family, like the Barnes and Park families in our show.

 

MEET THE TEAM!

Bottom L-R: Alexandro Pacheco (Producer), Kayla Lewis (Showrunner), Luke Salin (Director), Elizabeth Bescherer (Production Designer)

Middle L-R: Elizabeth Rezende (Assistant Director), Annie Swenson (Executive Producer), Cole Bannick (Producer), Jori Johnson (Producer)

Top L-R: San Yvin (Director of Photography), Alp Çağatay (Casting Director) 

 

THE CHALLENGES WE'LL FACE!

As you can imagine, making a 30-minute television pilot comes with a lot of obstacles. Just a few possible challenges include...

  • Being able to feed a cast/crew of over 25: On student films, cast and crew aren’t being paid, so the most the production can offer them is a set that includes wonderfully cooked meals and provides the appropriate snacks to sustain that cast and crew of 25 over the course of 6 long, 12-hour shoot days. 
  • Making sure we are minimizing our carbon footprint: Doing our part for the environment is important, so we have committed to creating a green set and will have a dedicated Green Manager who’s job it is to ensure we are not only recycling properly but using as many biodegradable products and food ingredients on set (we want to show our commitment to this and thus are seeking a donor who is equally committed to that cause)

Above are just a few possible challenges that will arise during pre-production and production. Luckily, since the creation of this show is a part of an official NYU class, we are given class time to meet with one another! During this time (about 10 hours a week), we have the opportunity to collaborate and work together to solve problems that arise. Even though we are still students, every single one of us is wholeheartedly committed to creating the best show possible. 

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP US! 

We completely understand that not everyone is able to donate - and want you to know that there are so many ways that you can help us turn this show into a reality!

  • Follow us on social media and show us some love!!! You can follow us on Facebook and Instagram @parkedinamericashow. The more people that follow us, the more people will find out about our show! 
  • Share our fundraiser! Every share on Facebook, mention on Instagram, and Twitter shoutout matters. 
  • Help us connect with other Asian creatives! A huge hope of ours is that we will be able to collaborate and gain attention from Asian creatives in the entertainment industry. Almost all of our department heads (including the Showrunner, Director, Executive Producer, Cinematographer, and Production Designer) are of Asian descent. We would love to connect with other Asian creatives to gain industry insight and advice! 
  • Donate food or locations! We are going to have to feed over 25 cast and crew members and are always looking for more snacks to have on set! In addition, we are actively looking for a school and home to film in! Have any leads or connections? Let us know (reach out to us at parkedinamericashow@gmail.com)! 

 

Want to contact us? Email us at parkedinamericashow@gmail.com

We are so excited to bring this story to life! Thank you!!!

story:
Hello!

We are making a new comedy series called WAGS TO RICHES.

 

WAGS TO RICHES is a story about two middle aged guys who lose their jobs and decide to start a doggy daycare in their garage – because they think it sounds like it’s easy. Except neither of them knows anything about dogs. 

The show was written by us: Tony Camin and Ali MacLean.  We've written and performed on TV before. You can check out our credits below.

Now, this isn't just any comedy show. It's a chance to see your favorite actors and comedians - with their real dogs.

We have regulars on the show, like Mark Fite from Tenacious D's Festival Supreme and Two Headed Dog, and Samm Levine from Freaks And Geeks and Wet Hot American Summer. Plus a whole bunch of professional canine stars, who have more training than the both of us.

Each week a special celebrity guest star will come on with their dog, interacting with both the human and canine actors. Some people who have expressed interest in appearing on the show include: Tom Lennon, Neil Hamburger, Maria Bamford, Margaret Cho, Ron Lynch, Brian Posehn, Jon Daly, Iliza Shlesinger, Baron Vaughn, Lauren Weedman,  Howard Kremer, Mike O'Connell, Jerry Minor, and more.

We have some networks interested in our show, so we are raising money to make the pilot and show them how great it would be to see this on the air every week. It's funny and it has dogs, and who doesn't love funny dogs?

Plus, because we believe in comedy for good, a portion of the profits will be donated to Best Friends NKLA, a no kill shelter here in Los Angeles. So it's like we are making important art AND saving lives.

You can help us achieve our goal  - make the pilot and help dogs find homes!

 

THE CAST:

Tony Camin

Tony has appeared on Late Night with Conan O'Brien, Jimmy Kimmel Live, Real Time with Bill Maher, and lots of others that have been cancelled. He's has performed at The Just For Laughs festival in Montreal as well as The HBO US Comedy Arts Festival  in Aspen, as well as the Melbourne Comedy festival in Australia. Tony has written for programs on NBC, VH1, and Comedy Central. In addition to being co-creator/ performer of "The Marijuana-Logues", he can also be seen as a correspondent for "The Media Project", on IFC, and was a recent contestant on NBC's Last Comic Standing.

 

Mark Fite

Mark Fite is an American actor and comedian. He is a founding member of the L.A. based comedy group 2 Headed Dog and has performed at The Comedy Store, The Improv, Upright Citizens Brigade, The Comedy Festival in Las Vegas, The U.S. Comedy Arts Festival in Aspen, San Francisco SketchFest, Tenacious D’s Festival Supreme, Lucha VaVoom and Brookledge Follies. He also works in film, television, commercials, voice over, and theatre.

 

Samm Levine

Samm Levine's first breakout role was as a member of the "geek" half of the short lived cult hit, Freaks and Geeks.

The following year, he rejoined "Freaks and Geeks" producer, Judd Apatow, for another widely praised coming of age series, Undeclared. That same year, Samm made his feature debut in the raucous teen spoof, Not Another Teen Movie.

Since then, he has appeared in over 60 films and television shows, including the Oscar winning Quentin Tarantino epic, Inglourious Basterds, and in many memorable roles on beloved programs such as Entourage, Modern Family, NCIS and How I Met Your Mother. In addition to his growing catalog of television appearances, Samm is also known for roles in many cult features, including the Broken Lizard comedy, Club Dread, the sci-fi thriller, Pulse, and acclaimed indie comedies, Drones and IFC's Made for Each Other. He is currently starring in the Wet Hot American Summer series on Netflix.

 

Ali MacLean

Ali MacLean is an award winning writer and comedian who hailsfrom Boston. Ali studied at the LaJolla Playhouse and at The Groundlings. Her short films have won festival awards and her short MEDIA WHORE, which she starred in, was optioned by Saturday Night Live producers as a television pilot. Ali has written for various networks, including MTV, VH-1, and FOX. She created the MTV pilot TOWN MAUL and wrote for MTV2’s updated version of CELEBRITY DEATHMATCH, as well as for KATHY GRIFFIN. Ali worked on comedies such as THE JIMMY KIMMEL SHOW, HBO’s MR. SHOW with Bob Odenkirk and David Cross, and THE GREEN ROOM with PAUL PROVENZA. Recently, Ali created the web series LAW OF THE LAND, which she wrote and starred in for the SYD BUTLER and DAVID CROSS owned FKR TV, in conjunction with The Orchard. Her comedy series LADY KILLER was developed with SUPER DELUXE, a wing of TURNER NETWORKS.

Ali has performed comedy everywhere including at SF SketchFest, The Improv, The Comedy Store, Hotel Cafe, and Largo.

 

The Canine Cast:

 

Dummy

Dummy has been seen on the Onion News Network, and featured in the New York Times. Sure, only a couple of things but remember, she's a dog.

 

Finley

Finley likes swimming and sports. She can do tricks, but she won't roll over for just anybody.

 

Penny

Penny is into cosplay and watching stand up comedy.

 

Honey Bear

Meet Honey Bear. Her interests are cheeseburgers and accessorizing.

 

Cody

Cody likes chasing small squirrels and big dreams.

 

Sanford

Sanford is a New York actor trained in the Mesiner technique. Here he shows off his range.

She created the MTV pilot TOWN MAUL and wrote for MTV2’s updated version of CELEBRITY DEATHMATCH, as well as for KATHY GRIFFIN. Ali worked on comedies such as THE JIMMY KIMMEL SHOW, HBO’s MR. SHOW with Bob Odenkirk and David Cross, and THE GREEN ROOM with PAUL PROVENZA. Recently, Ali created the web series LAW OF THE LAND, which she wrote and starred in for the SYD BUTLER and DAVID CROSS owned FKR TV, in conjunction with The Orchard. Her comedy series LADY KILLER was developed with SUPER DELUXE, a wing of TURNER NETWORKS.Ali has performed comedy everywhere including at SF SketchFest, The Improv, The Comedy Store, Hotel Cafe, and Largo. The Canine Cast: DummyDummy has been seen on the Onion News Network, and featured in the New York Times. Sure, only a couple of things but remember, she's a dog. FinleyFinley likes swimming and sports. She can do tricks, but she won't roll over for just anybody. PennyPenny is into cosplay and watching stand up comedy. Honey BearMeet Honey Bear. Her interests are cheeseburgers and accessorizing. CodyCody likes chasing small squirrels and big dreams. SanfordSanford is a New York actor trained in the Mesiner technique. Here he shows off his range.

story:
Show Title:  theTHREE

Format: 3 person panel each episode (body, mind & spirit experts)
Rationale: Current Events & Issues are discussed with body, mind & spirit solutions
Pilot Shoots: January 13, 2018
Duration: 30 minutes (eventually, 60 minutes)
Location: Live studio audience at Eastgate Creative Christian Fellowship in Nashville, TN
Target Audience: Culture-Conscious 20s-60s

story:
Short Summary

In our first year together, we were learning. We wanted to become actors with a well rounded understanding of filmmaking and the ability to create and follow through on our ideas, rather than actors who were just trying to get hired on whatever project we could find an audition for. We made ten short films in twelve months with a budget of about $120 for each (go to www.thursdayAF.com to see them).  But now our skills and imaginations have blossomed into what is now Wild Wild Yogis! A show about five social media influencers that attend an exclusive yoga retreat led by a spiritual Guru, where they are confronted with the hard truths hiding behind their online personas.

Five writers spent weeks with the original pitch, brainstorming ideas and breaking the episodes, the characters, and the story arc. Two producers looked over all that work, offering perspective and reminding us we couldn't shoot a car crash or blow up a ranch. After a series of rewrites, table reads, rehearsals and one fundraiser on the books, we have 4 days in the can which enabled us to cut together this super fun trailer! However, we still need six more days of shooting in order to finish production. Then of course the post production process begins! Editing, color correcting and sound mixing will make this project look (and sound) like something you'd find on a Hulu Original series without all the bureaucratic run-around. This series comes from our hearts, and we can't wait to share it with the world!

The only way to do that is through your contributions. Although we have self-funded half of the project, we are simply unable to do this alone. Each contribution creates a web that supports our budget, which is mostly spent on the camera and sound departments. We also have some location fees, post production costs, and the all important need to feed our cast and crew. Without contributors, Wild Wild Yogis will be stuck in film limbo like so many projects that don't have a community to support them. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $5,000 to finish shooting Wild Wild Yogis. We'll need more once we get into post production, but our main focus is to get the episodes in the can before the summer is over. 

  • $2,700 of this amount goes to pay our cinematographers, and rent our camera and lighting gear.
  • $900 goes to our sound specialist,
  • $250 for our location fees, 
  • $900 to keep the crew happy with full tummies!

As incentives, we've come up with a few really cool gifts.

  • $25 gift incentive is an autographed photograph of the entire cast and crew.
  • $150 gift incentive ADDS an orange #namafuckinste t-shirt just like our yogis wear in the show.
  • $500 gift incentive ADDS a DVD of all 6 episodes (Nobody else in the WORLD will have a hard copy except people at this donation level).
  • $1000 gift incentive ADDS 2 VIP tickets to our exclusive wrap party.
  • $2500 ADDS an Executive Producer credit. This means that the project will have your name on it.
  • As a special incentive, the donor with the highest gift donation will be given the actual peace pipe used in the filming of this show.

The Impact

Wild Wild Yogis was created out of a need to take control of our futures in Hollywood. We're not waiting to be hired on a project; we're creating our own. We're not hoping a project is well-written; we're crafting something from our hearts, our vulnerabilities, and our funny bones. When you contribute, you support each of us in these efforts. 

You also support the story; and through the story, you support each viewer. This show is hilarious, but it touches on difficult issues with which people struggle in everyday life such as emotional abuse, depression, gender identity, and diversity. We highlight the cult-like nature of social media, the dichotomy between real life and the way it's presented for the masses, the manipulation behind popularity, and the breakdown of spirit that comes when you put your faith in fame.

Risks & Challenges

Making a film is always a puzzle and a challenge, and with Wild Wild Yogis there are several hurdles to jump.
First, we are shooting outside on location: we have to get our shots scheduled that day within the daylight we have. No studio interior and lights to give us endless day. That challenge is amplified with negotiating the sound of our scenes with the sound of planes flying over the valley.
We don’t have unlimited time, either: to shoot WWY we only have 6 more days, due to budget and cast and crew availability. So we must be able to make our days (filmmaker lingo for getting all that day’s planned shots DONE), and as we are a union project - we must get everything done within the union timeframes we are allowed for shooting.

Post Production:
Remember those airplane noises we have to navigate? Well it’s not just those, other things can make their way into our sound files, like the crinkle of tarp from our tent interiors, wind, or dogs barking. So we need to clean up those audio tracks and then also add in the sounds that truly bring the auditory film to life. Ambient sounds, sound effects, music, etc. Also in post production the film will need coloring: to make all the brilliant colors of WWY production design pop on screen.

Distribution: and then there is the challenge of getting g WWY out there: spreading the word,  submitting to film fests, and pitching the series to platforms like Amazon and Hulu.

We are eager and ready for the challenges, but all this can only move forward if WWY is funded the rest of the way.

Other Ways You Can Help

Every contribution helps us reach our goal. If dollar bills are difficult for you at this time, there are many other ways you can help.

  • First, just share this link and the trailer. The more people who see this campaign, the better. Not only does it help raise more money, it raises awareness of the project.
  • A huge help is donating hot lunches for our cast and crew during filming days. We shoot long hours, and one way to show the team we love them is through FOOD.
  • Post production assistance. Once we've finished shooting everything, we are going to need a lot of help in the post production area of expertise. Donations of time, or even referrals to great folks that may work below their going rate help tremendously.

That's it for now! Thanks for reading about our show. We can't wait to have you involved and show you the finished product!

story:
Short Summary

Can we make you believe in the magic of cinema over three short webisodes? We’re a team of Sydney-based film students and we’re going to try our best! ‘Le Cinéma’ has become more than just an assessment piece. The story explores something deeply personal and accessible to all people with a love of film. 

 

Meet the Cast

Geoffrey Cordner (role of Tony)

Geoff is an Australian actor with most of his experience pertaining to the mid to late 1990s when he appeared in a host of TV shows and commercials. Since returning to acting in 2016, Geoff’s passion for acting has been reignited, and we couldn’t be more thrilled to have him as our leading man. 

 

Rebecca Mathews (role of Maddi)

Rebecca is an Australian born Actress, classically trained in theatre, film, and television. With abilities that include singing, directing and teaching and as a mother of four, Rebecca’s skills are many and varied. Her work has taken her between Sydney, LA & NYC and we are lucky enough to have her here on our shoot.

 

Lani Castle (role of Erin)

Lani is a young and incredibly talented actress who has professional acting credits spanning over the past decade. Since graduating from acting school in 2016, she has been navigating the local industry at an impressive pace, and we couldn't be more excited to see what she can do on Le Cinéma. 

 

Why Are We Crowdfunding?

Whilst we are generously allocated a small budget from our university, it isn’t quite enough to cover our expenses. Your much-appreciated contributions will go towards: 

  • Venue hire and expenses (filming in a cinema is not exactly straightforward)
  • Cast and crew transport & catering (most of the cast & crew lives in the outer west)
  • Production design & costuming

None of the money raised will be spent frivolously, with all proceeds going directly towards shooting necessities in alignment with our comprehensive budget. Every single one of our cast and crew is invaluable to this production and your funding and support will go a long way towards ensuring they can contribute to this project. 

 

Our Goal

When we dream, we dream big! We would love to see this web-series screening at short film festivals globally. Since ‘Le Cinéma’s inception people have been excited to see where it will go and have wanted to see it grow to be something bigger. We’d love for that to happen too, so depending on where this project takes us, the story may not end here. 

Some major factors regarding the success of this series include: 

  • Each of our crew members is in their element and is 100% dedicated to their role
  • The entire series has been shot in 4k using a RED Scarlet Gemini
  • Whilst our actors aren’t globally famous (yet) they all possess that special star-quality that made them the perfect fits straight from their auditions

 

Other Ways You Can Help

This may be the only time you see artists asking to be paid in exposure! If you are unable to contribute, please help us out by liking and sharing our Instagram or Facebook pages. Keep an eye on our feeds for any exciting news, and thank you for your time.

@le_cinema_anthology

story:
Dear family and friends,

 

I am creating a web series called “Hooked” that will target girls in their teens and young adults. The show follows a socially awkward girl in college as she navigates through life with the unfortunate circumstances of peer pressure both in dating and social scene among other girls. 

 

There are many life lessons that viewers will learn from this show including staying true to what you believe in, never giving up, and never changing your values to impress others. 

 

The budget is $30,000. Any contribution to help make this happen, no matter how big or small, would help. Please contribute through indegogo.com. For anyone who contributes over $500 will get a producer credit as well as a walk on role if you want to be filmed (Dates for that are late Sept - early Oct).

 

Thank you for reading and for your contribution,

 

Brittany

story:
We're back.

The anticipated next episode of niche online news satire Looking Into Lockout Laws dives deeper into the investigation of Queensland and New South Wales' controversial reduced alcohol service laws, their effect on nightlife, and how Australian drinking culture stacks up compared with the rest of the world.

Combining legitimate research with quirky man-on-the-street reporting with late night partygoers, sometimes it’s serious business and others it’s literally gutter journalism - in a good way.

The first episode was entirely self-produced, with the help of a few Brisbane late night venues who let us film there. In Part 2, we want to up the stakes in the scale, quality and goals of the series... but we need your help.

 

What the eff is this?

Looking Into Lockout Laws is a series of online comedy investigations by Brisbane filmmaker and satirist Martin Ingle. With sharp wit and tongue firmly in cheek, earnest fake journalist Martin investigates Queensland’s recent slate of reduced alcohol service laws, as well as the paradigm of lockout laws which have taken hold across Australia in recent years.

  • Do these laws actually work to reduce “alcohol-fueled violence” as politicians claim?
  • Is the impact on small businesses and the late night economy too much?
  • Why are casinos conveniently exempt from these laws?
  • And what does this say about Australia’s relationship with alcohol, if similar laws don’t exist in other thriving modern cities?

Through man-on-the-street reporting and interviews with key stakeholders, Looking Into Lockout Laws is the nightlife’s fun, inventive response to a timely, serious issue.

Throughout the episodes, the previously square and straight-laced Martin goes on a personal journey of discovery too, learning that safe drinking habits are essential to a good night out, and overall emphasising that no matter what the laws are in place, personal responsibility while drinking is the key that all sides of the issues can agree on.

In Episode 1, naive reporter Martin hit the streets to get a first-hand perspective on the effect of Queensland’s reduced service laws. After a night on the town interviewing venue owners and getting a bit silly with notorious Brisbane City Councillor Jonathan “Rainbow Scarf” Sri, it seemed clear that the laws were having a detrimental effect on small businesses in the night-time economy. But what other factors are at play?

That's what we are going to find out in Part 2.

 

About Part 2

Dead set on diving even deeper into the issue, the previously straight-laced Martin sets out to find out how late night culture differs around the world. What is so different about Australia that we have found it necessary to implement these laws? Do we have an unsafe drinking culture? What can we do to promote responsible consumption of alcohol?

In Europe, Martin will hit the streets on a night out, similarly getting a sense of the nightlife culture in a bustling cultural metropolis like Barcelona. Through interviews with people on the street, patrons, as well as venue owners in Europe, Martin compares our two drinking cultures, leading to the inevitable unanswerable conclusion: what is so different about Aussies?

Are we more violent? Are we more irresponsible? Do we drink more? Should we drink less? Do reduced service of alcohol and lockout laws like those in QLD and NSW target street violence appropriately? Why does Europe not have them or, apparently, need them?

 

Europe? WTF?

Martin and some crew will already be in Europe in September 2018 for a variety of other reasons, so the opportunity to film content for the series on a minimal budget was one that was too perfect to ignore.

In this way, the budget for Episode 2 is dramatically lower than it would be if planning the production from scratch as most airfares, accommodation and per diem costs are drastically reduced - after all, we are already in Europe so we don’t need funding to get there.

 

One more thing...

We are also seeking brand partners to assist in covering costs. We are looking for brave, fun corporate sponsors who are keen to reach our audience of smart young people in new, inventive ways.

Know anybody? Send them our way!

martin.p.writer@gmail.com

 

Finally... thank you for your support! If you don't have the $ to chuck in at the moment, then you can still follow Martin Ingle on Facebook for updates and to see when the video goes live.

story:
Now supported by:

For the next week (from Tuesday 19 June), the Merton Floats will double any donation made up to a total of £200. Now is your chance to help us make this happen!

*

“But Dorian – think about profile pictures! We look at each other like art. We exhibition ourselves."​

What is it?

This ambitious project began over three years with one of our writers and directors, Tara Snelling, who wanted to relocate Oscar Wilde's gothic thrillerThe Picture of Dorian Gray to modern student life.

With the hard work and enthusiasm of many student filmmakers, we now have Dorian. Our talented team of over thirty crew and cast members have already shot four of the six planned episodes of our series, produced and filmed at Oxford University. Yet, with very little funding available to us, we kindly ask for your generous donations in order to cover our costs and finish our web series.  

Who are we?

Our team is made up of skilled undergraduates and postgraduates who have worked on several successful projects, as well as introducing newcomers to the film scene to experience what it's like to be on a set. Our all female core crew - three incredible producers, three directors, and four writers - have been intensely committed to bringing this project to life for a year or longer.

We are all aspiring to enter a notoriously difficult industry, and projects like this are essential an first step.

Why Dorian?

We want to authentically capture what it’s like to be at university at a time where professional filmmakers fall short, particularly with Oxbridge (think: The Riot Club). Our university on screen is unrecognisable, as media – both tabloid and fictional – either romanticises its prestige or fetishizes its problems.

Dorian follows the six birthdays of five friends over the course of a year, starting with eager fresher Amelia Dorian (Bea Udale-Smith) on her first day of university. Manipulative and reckless, she flirts with fellow fresher and artistic old soul Basil Hallward (Rowan Wilson), before flitting to the magnetic debating society president Henry Wotton (Rory Grant). To get away with anything and dodge the consequences of her actions, Amelia quickly realises image is everything.

Victorian social fears often match the millennial appearance obsessed university experience, and our web series, like Wilde's book, touches on the purpose of art, social superficiality, youth culture and the pain of casual relationships. We have swapped the genders of most characters and explored a range of sexualities in order to accurately realities of modern university.

We hope students relate to and recognise their friends in all of our characters, and we aim to make every event that happens – even ones which seem extreme - sound like a story which could have happened to a friend-of-a-friend, or which we have experienced ourselves.

Where will the funding go?

The first four episodes of Dorian were shot in two stages in January and March 2018. We plan to shoot the final two episodes in June 2018. In order to cover the cost of equipment hire, props and costumes, catering, and locations on all three separate shoots we are hoping to raise £1,500. This will enable us to cover our existing expenses and cover our final two episodes.

In order to make this multi-episode project the best it can possibly be, we've invested our budget into exciting props, unique locations and lighting equipment. We hope to release our web series in its entirety online, after we have submitted it into festivals and held a screening in Oxford.

KIT: £ 885 | We have been very fortunate to be able to use the Oxford University Film Foundation's equipment free of charge, which has greatly reduced our production costs. However, we still need funds to cover cost of some equipment hired externally - including lights and batteries - and insurance.

LOCATIONS: £ 350 | We have been working hard to secure locations that capture the archaic aesthetic that we have been aiming for in this web series. While the results will absolutely be worth it, but this hasn’t been free of charge.

COSTUMES: £ 120 and PROPS: £ 70 | We have been lucky to have had a fantastic team to design costumes and select props, which will help to evoke the Victorian roots of this story. 

CATERING: £ 75 | Catering costs have been kept to a minimum throughout this production. However, we are hoping to fund a small amount to cover basic snacks and drinks supplied to the cast and crew on set.

Our talented team of over thirty crew and cast members have already shot four of the six planned episodes of our series, produced and filmed at Oxford University. story:
What Happened

For years, Joanna had been secretly compiling group texts from her very best friends about their various work stories and shenanigans, as well as her own. All along she threatened to write them into a web series, and one day, they unexpectedly came rolling out of her and into a script.

She's lucky that her best friend, Mira, also happens to be an enormously talented (but surprisingly unsuccessful) actor, who has been a part of bringing similar projects to life. A long time ago, Mira discovered Joanna's superb writing skills and had been looking for an opportunity to ride those coat tails for a while.

And thus was born, "Formal Complaints". It's a hilariously written series inspired by real life events and dramatic humans, and what would happen if you combined them all into one tiny space and forced them to intersect.

Joanna and Mira plan to shoot this summer (2019), and make something spectacular for your viewing pleasure, to be released publicly on the internet. It's a passion project in many ways: we are passionate about the script, passionate about our talents, and passionate about each other.

Please Help Us

So this is the awkward part where we ask you to break out your wallets. 

Here's the deal: regardless of how much of a budget we get, we are making this thing. There's no question.

However, we would really love to have our ideal budget behind us so we can realize this dream as much as possible and make something that we can be really proud of. Considering we are still young millennials and need to pay for silly things like food and a roof over our heads, we are hoping to offset the funds as much as we can.

Here's a brief rundown of where some of your donations will be spent:

  • Food. We're going to have to feed a lot of people.
  • Props & Costumes
  • Equipment Rentals (Lights, sound, etc.)
  • Website Fees & Editing Software

The Impact

Ultimately, the goal is to create a professional quality show that is easily accessible to you (the public) that's hilariously entertaining, relatable and memorable.

As well, we have a... unique... sense of humour, especially when we combine forces, that we are ready to unleash upon the world. Our communal strange brand of humour was born when we, just two young ladies (who no one would ever think would have anything in common), somehow connected in our souls and stuck by each other through the weirdest times of our lives. That heart and humour is interwoven into the Formal Complaints script, and we think that it will be a really special experience for our eventual audience. Or horrifying. Who knows?

Mira has been a part of many a web series in the past, and is confident that the knowledge of the talented people she has worked with has rubbed off on her. We have great people in our corner, and Mira is not afraid to bug every single person she knows in the industry with questions.

Lastly, we really are two people that can make anything happen, and that's 90% of the battle.

Other Ways You Can Help

We get it. Not everyone has money to throw around at things that haven't even been made yet. Totally cool. If you'd still like to help us out non-monetarily (or even in addition to monetarily), here are some ways you can do so:

  • Spread the word!!! Share our campaign. Share our Facebook and Instagram pages (both are @formalcomplaints). Share our website: formalcomplaintsseries.com. Oh and give the show a watch when it comes out, yeah?
  • Are you a thespian or think you could be good at acting and live in Calgary? Come out and audition for us! Keep up to date on our Facebook and Instagram so you don't miss when we post auditions.
  • Do you have experience working on set? Come play with us! We will be hiring many crew positions throughout the summer, through our Facebook and Instagram.
  • Are you insanely organized and enthusiastic, but have no (or only some) prior experience on set? Come play with us too. Personality and a thirst for knowledge matter too.

story:
About Our Series

Co-Created and run by two USC School of Cinematic Arts students, Hannah Ceselski and Sara Linden, Funny Business is inspired by their real life experience working on a college television show. And all eight episodes have already been written so it's up to you to help it get made!

The series itself focuses on an eclectic mix of student writers and producers working on The Wednesday Show, a live comedy show on their college TV station. If not for the show, they would never speak to each other. As it stands, they spend far too much time together.

In this show, created by people who liked "Studio 60" far too much, we see what happens to this team under fire. Adventures are had and secrets are kept. There's sabotage and gags that go on far too long. The stakes are inexplicably high, and the tensions between the staff members are alarmingly sexual.

Pictured: aforementioned sexual tension

Why You Should Get Involved

Investing in Funny Business means supporting unique, strong, female voices and creating a safe space for us to learn and experiment—outside of the classroom.

With this web series our team will gain the knowledge of what it takes to lead a writers room, run a TV series, handle finances, and communicate with a team of brilliant people.

Our Team

Hannah Ceselski – Co-Creator, Showrunner, and Executive Producer

Hannah is a USC sophomore screenwriting student. She hails from Missouri and hopes she never has to go back. She is a staff writer on the Trojan Vision show “The Breakdown” and the current Editor-in-Chief of The Sack of Troy, a campus satire magazine. She became interested in comedy because she wasn’t pretty or good at sports. One time at a birthday party, she was given a plaque that said “Most Dramatic,” and it still drives her to this day.

She is the Co-Creator and Co-Showrunner of Funny Business, which is inspired by her experiences in the college comedy circle. She has always dreamt of leading her own comedy series -- and now that dream is becoming a reality.

Sara Linden – Co-Creator, Showrunner, and Executive Producer

Sara is a senior who came to USC from Missouri to become a screenwriter, and she’s trying her best which is all we can ask of her. She works for the Trojan Vision show “The Breakdown” as a Senior Producer, The Sack of Troy as a Staff Writer/Photo Editor, and she has been making people listen to her music in the car since 1996. She became interested in comedy because she WAS pretty AND good at sports. Take that, Hannah!

She’s the Co-Creator and Co-Showrunner for Funny Business, and she is very excited to start shooting (with a camera, not a gun).

Roma Murphy – Producer, Staff Writer

Roma came all the way from New York City to Los Angeles just to work on Funny Business. Somehow along the way she stumbled into the screenwriting major at USC, in which she is now a sophomore. She is also a staff writer on “The Breakdown,” but does not write for the Sack of Troy like her Co-Creator counterparts because she avoids all writing that isn’t in screenplay format like the plague. Somebody once told her that if you can’t laugh you’ll cry, so after years of being called a crybaby by the bigger kids, she finally learned her lesson and turned to comedy.

She originally joined the Funny Business team as the writer of episodes 3 and 6, but then Hannah and Sara thought she had moxie and promoted her to Producer. She plans to repay them with her first child, but for now she’ll just settle for helping bring their show to life.

Lauren Foley – Producer

Lauren is a junior majoring in Narrative Studies and minoring in Cinematic Arts at the University of Southern California. Lauren keeps herself busy at USC as the Vice President of the Women of Cinematic Arts (WCA) where she curates student events to foster a community of female driven filmmakers. As a Vice President and executive board member, Lauren’s responsibilities include event planning, managing her team, and producing projects for student outreach. 

Outside of WCA, Lauren has also gained ample experience working both in front of and behind the camera on over 12 different productions, both student and professional, and at two production companies, Daniel L. Paulson Productions and Sony Pictures Entertainment. 

With Funny Business, Lauren is excited to bring her personal experiences working at the college television parody news show “The Breakdown” to life and work with the amazing and impassioned Funny Business team.

The Logistics

With an 8 episode (10-12 minute episodes) first season already written, Funny Business will be shot over 8 weekends, with 1 6 days of shooting total. Each shoot day will range from 10-12 hours, adding up to 20-24 hour weekend shoots.  

Budget

Luckily, since our Funny Business crew is made up of film students, our show has access to personal cameras and equipment for the shoot, which knocks out a major category from our budget.

However, with an ensemble cast and crew, a huge portion of our budget will go towards catering and craft services to ensure everyone gets fed. Following that, locations will be our next biggest spend, with miscellaneous (props, costumes, etc.) and distribution/festival fees bringing us to a total budget of $2,600.

 

Our Cast of Characters

Danny Helms as “PARKER”

Parker is one of the two showrunners on The Wednesday Show. He is passionate and ambitious, but also egotistical and condescending. He loves The Wednesday Show and wants to see it succeed, but this pursuit often causes him to be closed-minded.

 

Leeanna Albanese as “CAROLINE”

Caroline is The Wednesday Show’s new co-showrunner. She is the opposite of Parker. Caroline is manic and excitable, always looks on the bright side, and is absolutely nothing if not unpredictable.

 

Hannah Ceselski as “NORA”

Nora is The Wednesday Show’s script supervisor. She is the self-proclaimed protégé of Parker and spends her time trying to balance out the strong personalities at the station and keep everything afloat.

 

Colin McIsaac as “LOGAN”

Logan is a writer on The Wednesday Show. He thinks he's hot shit despite actually being obnoxious and kind of dorky. He is undeclared and lazy, and he would never try to hide it. 

 

Max Banta as “DAN”

Dan is the graphics guy for The Wednesday Show. He’s the resident frat boy who loves to party but gets angry fast. Dan recently flunked out of anger management again.

 

Sara Linden as “DYLAN”

Dylan is another writer on The Wednesday Show. She is a true tomboy and not The Wednesday Show's sharpest staff member. Her closest friends are Caroline and her trusty yoyo.

 

Support Us!

Find us on social media and track our team as we move through the pre-production, production, and post-production process to see how we're doing! And invest in a donation "perk" to receive even better BTS content and interactive materials, such as character mix tapes and letters.

Follow us on 

  • Facebook – /FunnyBusinessMiniseries
  • Instagram – @FunnyBusinessMiniseries

story:
Short Summary

Abbey Fenbert plays BECK, a happy modern feminist. Emily Harpe plays CLEM, a woman from the nether-centuries. Beck introduces Clem to online dating, intersectional feminism, electricity, pants, moral relativism, Hamilton, and, of course, Second Wine. Clem tries to maintain her value system while living her best future life. We guarantee that you’ll laugh, and that no men get to talk.

Thanks for your support of BECK & CLEM!

Boooooo the Past. #TeamFuture

What We Need & What You Get

We have everything we need to shoot Season One — except the support of some generous backers and co-producers. We’re operating on a small budget. Your contribution will cover the costs of equipment and basic supplies, and help us pay our production team. In return you’ll be eligible for our lovely perks, including co-producer credit. If a donation isn’t possible, no worries: We’d be very grateful if you gave us a shout-out on social media or passed word along to your friends!

The Team

Abbey — Writer/Creator

plays BECK: “Nothing these men have to say is of any value.”

Abbey Fenbert is a playwright from Detroit, MI. She values empathy, honesty and resisting fascist regimes. Plus, jokes! Her award-winning comedy INTENTIONS premiered at Matrix Theatre Company (co-starring Emily Harpe) in February 2017 and her all-female historical drama SICKLE was a Finalist for the 2016 National Playwrights Conference. Her writing can also be found online at The Toast, McSweeney’s, HowlRound, The Offing and American Theatre Magazine. She holds a BA from NYU and an MFA from Boston University, and is currently based in Los Angeles.

About Emily — Co-Creator

plays CLEM: “Pleasure! Where I come from it is not a concept, only another name for the devil.”

Emily Harpe is a performer in Detroit. She's currently appearing in the professional world premiere of Abbey Fenbert's INTENTIONS as Lou, a role she also played in the un-professional world premiere: a student production at IU, which she also produced and co-directed. She was last seen in RE-RELEASE PARTY (THE GOLDEN RECORD) with A Host of People, and has performed throughout Chicago, most notably as an improviser at iO Theater and CIC Theater. She holds an MFA in Acting from Indiana University and BA from Kalamazoo College. She loves democracy, equality, and Springsteen.

About Three Lyons Creative

Three Lyons Creative (3LC) is a multi-media production company based in Detroit, specializing in video, audio, graphic design, and illustration. Through community groups, artists, nonprofits, and businesses both large and small, 3LC strives to tell honest and people-focused stories with pride. 3LC produced the short film Thick Air in 2015, funded by a successful Indiegogo campaign. It was reviewed favorably in the Detroit Free Press and shown at the NYC Independent Film Festival. With a love for social humor, the 3LC team could not be more excited to help bring Abbey and Emily's hilarious vision to life.

Three Lyons Creative team includes: Tony Eggert, Daniel Wylie-Eggert, Mike Williams, and Lucia Wylie-Eggert

Other Ways You Can Help

If a donation isn’t possible, no worries: We’d be very grateful if you gave us a shout-out on social media or passed word along to your friends!

Short Summary
Abbey Fenbert plays BECK, a happy modern feminist. Emily Harpe plays CLEM, a woman from the nether-centuries. Beck introduces Clem to online dating, intersectional feminism, electricity, pants, moral relativism, Hamilton, and, of course, Second Wine. Clem tries to maintain her value system while living her best future life. We guarantee that you’ll laugh, and that no men get to talk.
Thanks for your support of BECK & CLEM!
Boooooo the Past. #TeamFuture

What We Need & What You Get
We have everything we need to shoot Season One — except the support of some generous backers and co-producers. We’re operating on a small budget. Your contribution will cover the costs of equipment and basic supplies, and help us pay our production team. In return you’ll be eligible for our lovely perks, including co-producer credit. If a donation isn’t possible, no worries: We’d be very grateful if you gave us a shout-out on social media or passed word along to your friends!

The Team
Abbey — Writer/Creator
plays BECK: “Nothing these men have to say is of any value.”
Abbey Fenbert is a playwright from Detroit, MI. She values empathy, honesty and resisting fascist regimes. Plus, jokes! Her award-winning comedy INTENTIONS premiered at Matrix Theatre Company (co-starring Emily Harpe) in February 2017 and her all-female historical drama SICKLE was a Finalist for the 2016 National Playwrights Conference. Her writing can also be found online at The Toast, McSweeney’s, HowlRound, The Offing and American Theatre Magazine. She holds a BA from NYU and an MFA from Boston University, and is currently based in Los Angeles.
About Emily — Co-Creator
plays CLEM: “Pleasure! Where I come from it is not a concept, only another name for the devil.”
Emily Harpe is a performer in Detroit. She's currently appearing in the professional world premiere of Abbey Fenbert's INTENTIONS as Lou, a role she also played in the un-professional world premiere: a student production at IU, which she also produced and co-directed. She was last seen in RE-RELEASE PARTY (THE GOLDEN RECORD) with A Host of People, and has performed throughout Chicago, most notably as an improviser at iO Theater and CIC Theater. She holds an MFA in Acting from Indiana University and BA from Kalamazoo College. She loves democracy, equality, and Springsteen.
About Three Lyons Creative
Three Lyons Creative (3LC) is a multi-media production company based in Detroit, specializing in video, audio, graphic design, and illustration. Through community groups, artists, nonprofits, and businesses both large and small, 3LC strives to tell honest and people-focused stories with pride. 3LC produced the short film Thick Air in 2015, funded by a successful Indiegogo campaign. It was reviewed favorably in the Detroit Free Press and shown at the NYC Independent Film Festival. With a love for social humor, the 3LC team could not be more excited to help bring Abbey and Emily's hilarious vision to life.
Three Lyons Creative team includes: Tony Eggert, Daniel Wylie-Eggert, Mike Williams, and Lucia Wylie-Eggert

Other Ways You Can Help
If a donation isn’t possible, no worries: We’d be very grateful if you gave us a shout-out on social media or passed word along to your friends!

story:
What It Is

  • The Real Manorwives of the Revolutionary War is a parody of the Real Housewives franchise currently airing on Bravo Tv. Our web series brings together some of the most important women of the 18th century and imagines what their daily dramas would be like had they all had the opportunity to truly socialize. What makes this web series different is we will strive to keep the language, references, costumes, etc as authentic to the time period as possible. 
  • By donating to our campaign you will be helping to bring an entirely female driven comedy series into fruition.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $5,000 towards the production of a full 5 episode season. (Each episode will be approx. 7 Minutes). Each Episode will then be uploaded to our website (currently under construction) for viewing!

We can’t do it without you!  Your donation towards our $5,000 budget will help cover:

  • Costumes & Props
  • Paying our sound person and amazing editor
  • Travel, and food
  • Web design and hosting
  • Location fees

We have so many amazing perks for you guys. Gifts, party invites, and even tickets to HAMILTON (It's true.)

 

Other Ways You Can Help

No donation is too small, but if you’re unable to contribute funds to the project, there are a ton of other ways you can help make The Real Manorwives amazing:

Post about our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, Google +, Linkedin, Snapchat- basically any and everyone of your social media accounts. Follow The Real Manorwives on Facebook  and share, share, share.!

Lend your skills!  If you’re a graphic designer, a seamstress, an experienced PA, etc ….we could use your help!  Contact us if you are interested in being part of our crew or production design team.

story:
National Digit Wrestling Association

Ahoy, 

My name is Doug Driesel Jr. I created The NDWA, or National Digit Wrestling Association. I also play twin brothers Baron von Satan and Baron von Lucifer. What is the NDWA, might you ask? It's Professional Thumb Wrestling (it's a thing)! We dress in costume, have entrance themes, cut promos, do ALL the stuff that they do on WWE, only when it comes time to throw each other around, we thumb wrestle. 

The most recent regular episode of NDWA Thursday Night Thumbderdome before the outbreak. 

 

We've been doing shows on the web, television, and in front of crowds since May of 2019. We have three webseries: NDWA Thursday Night Thumbderdome (our free show) and NDWA Sunday Thumbday (our Patreon-exclusive webseries) and NDWA Thumbs Squared (our "Social Distancing" show that temporarily replaced the other two while we can't get together). We've had four PPVs: ThumberSlam! '19, Thumb for the Holidays, January Jam 2020, and The Heavy Heads Thumb Monarch Tournament. We started a live show at The Springfield Improv just before the safer at home restrictions. We've done other live shows at The Outland. Our show NDWA Thursday Night Thumbderdome aired for 10 episodes on Mediacom Channel 85. We have designs on local broadcast television. 

Our very first episode of NDWA Thursday Night Thumbderdome from all the way back in May of 2019.
 

It's time to step up our production. And to us that means one thing: WE NEED A RING! 

If you've seen our product, you know that, while we've evolved over the last year, the vast majority of what we've shot, we've shot at a local arts center, creating a makeshift "ring" and "entry way" out of art display boards. But, we're ready to hit the big time! 

The second episode of NDWA Thumbs Squared, our "social distancing" show we're putting out during the outbreak. 
 

This campaign is to finance us getting a ring. The type of ring we are planning on getting is the cheapest ring. It's a 10'x10' "backyard wrestling ring." Where are we going to put it? In someone's two-car garage! And that will be NDWA's new headquarters! 

WE NEED A RING TO HIT THE BIG TIME, AND YOU GET TO SHOW HOW MUCH OF A FAN YOU ARE!!!

We've set the goal at $3,000. The ring itself is $1,600. The shipping on the ring is $500. That's $2,100. The rest goes toward operating fees (the instructions for the ring say we need to get some lumber for set-up, merch production for rewards) and IndieGoGo fees. 

The cast and crew of our first Pay-Per-View: ThumberSlam! '19

On the off chance we make more than our goal, that extra money will go to extra ring stuff. Ring aprons, signs, and so forth. 

We've got so many perks for you! Honestly, we'll be adding more all the time. You can get fan packages, appear on episodes of the show, advertise your business or even become our executive producer. 

Left to Right: Louie the Lush, DJ Valence, Baron von Lucifer and Avocado Kong making a live appearance at Heavy Heads Records in downtown Springfield.

If we don't reach our goal, our first step will be to pass the hat around all the wrestlers. If we still can't come up with enough to get the ring, we'll make the production look better in OTHER ways. Rent a boxing gym for filming? Get better lights? We'll use our money in the best ways possible.

 

The marquee at The Springfield Improv, where we do monthly live shows (when we're not under quarantine).

Professional Thumb Wrestling = The Next Cashew Chicken

Springfield, MO is known for Cashew Chicken. Soon, Springfield will be known for Thumb Wrestling. We'll be National sooner rather than later, but our home will always be in Springfield, MO! We've already made the front page of the Springfield News-Leader and we boast two local sponsors, always looking for more.

story:
Jazzed About It

"Each short film captures the essence of these young artists and their dedication to jazz." - Maria Traversa, Programmer, Jacob Burns Film Center "Jazz Sessions"

Jazzed About It is the new web series of short films spotlighting today's rising young jazz stars, with a unique look at their music and personal journeys in jazz.

In addition to showcasing the music of a variety of outstanding young artists, the mission of the project is to inspire a greater interest in jazz in the young audiences that will keep jazz alive and thriving in the 21st century. 

A PASSION FOR JAZZ

Jazz is widely regarded as one of America's greatest musical and cultural treasures, yet today it represents less than five percent of the music market.  Jazzed About It aims to remedy this by engaging young audiences with exciting, diverse young performers who share the passion for their music along with stories of the challenges and triumphs of life as a young jazz artist.  

JAZZ AND STORYTELLING

Each episode of Jazzed About It features a guest artist in conversation with another young artist acting as host. The format makes for a free-wheeling discussion of topics ranging from the influence of legendary jazz figures on their music, to how the societal aspects of jazz have shaped their experiences with it, to the important place mentors have had in their careers. All featured artists and hosts are compensated for their appearances in the series. 

CREATING NEW JAZZ FANS

As a web series of short, six to seven-minute films available for viewing at no charge, Jazzed About is designed to take advantage of the growing popularity of short form programming on the internet, especially among young viewers. Jazzed About It's website serves as a home base for the series and is a resource for more in-depth information about episodes and its featured artists. View the series' four premiere episodes at www.jazzedaboutit.com 

CRITICAL ACCLAIMI

In its limited launch, the series has already been recognized with Best Web Series awards at The New Orleans Second Line Film Festival and The Los Angeles Motion Picture Festival. 

Jazzed About It is produced and directed by filmmaker Jim Burns, whose PBS documentary about Jimmy Van Heusen follows the life and music of the four-time Oscar-winning songwriter whose timeless classics are some of the most revered in the jazz world. Burns's She's Got Jazz features four trailblazing young women artists who are changing the face of jazz in the 21st century. Jazzed About It is co-written by Jim Burns and Will Friedwald, author of ten books about American popular music and jazz including Jazz Singing and Straighten Up and Fly Right, a biography of Nat King Cole commemorating the singing legend's centennial year. 

FUNDING TO GO FORWARD 

As a jazz education project, Jazzed About It was launched with support by a foundation grant. Our mission now is to sustain the project and keep the series growing with the production of episodes featuring additional outstanding young artists. 

The current goal is the production of three or more additional episodes, raising funding to cover pre-production research and writing, location shooting, editing/graphics production, sound design, program distribution, website production, social media maintenance, administrative costs and appearance fees for featured artists and hosts.

Please join us in making it possible to continue to put the spotlight on rising young artists and bring their music to the next generation of jazz fans! 

Your contribution of any amount is welcome and very appreciated. Please see the Perks section for special offers.

story:
I HATE YOU, TOO is a low budget, comedy web series about two millennials in Chicago, Allie and Kevin, who learn to dish out the love and the *hate*

We're doing a season two because we are surprisingly funny, and shockingly capable to put our words onto a page and film it; thus (okay, we're scientists) creating our own work in such trying times like these. <3

WHAT WILL SEASON 2 LOOK LIKE?

  1. Quicker Episodes
  2. Better Acting
  3. Hilarious Writing

In this season of “I HATE YOU, TOO” Allie and Kevin...

  • Upgrade their digs!
  • Write a musical
  • Start a thriving business
  • Become TV stars
  • Party (duh!)

What We Need & What You Get

GOAL: $3500

What This Will Get Us...                                            

All the equipment we need to make Season 2 looking bomb as heck!

 
  • Pay for Artists

In Season 1, everyone was paid for their work, in food. (Thank you Domino’s and Taco Bell for your excellent service.) Now, as appealing as that is for some stomachs, it’s not enough for excellent artists to take time off from work, or make filming a priority. A lot of time and work goes into each second on screen, and we want artists to be compensated for that! We have actors, production crew, editing crew, and local musicians and visual artists that have done work for us in some capacity that we would love to pay for their service, because THEIR ART MATTERS!

 
  • Craft Services table on shoot days

Meals will be provided for all artists, all day long throughout the shoot of the web series. 

 
  • Marketing Opportunities

With money for marketing, we will be able to get the word out about I HATE YOU, TOO via instagram and facebook boosting, as well as advertisements on podcasts. And to top it off, fees for festival submissions usually add up pretty quick. If accepted to festivals, our work would be seen by many more spheres of influence we wouldn’t normally reach.

  • Other?

The last 5% of our budget will be a cushion for any unforeseen expenses that may come about. If we receive enough donations, this could go towards paying for production assistants, other artist pay, additional equipment, or marketing.

Minimum Goal : $1500 

  • We will have: the same lighting, video, and sound quality.
  • Artists paid a small stipend and will be fed on set. 

Season one was a completely zero budget project. We need at least $1500 to make the second season. This will get us the bare requirements of equipment for shooting and editing .  Artists will receive a very small stipend for their hard work, and will be provided with snacks and meals on set. Not much would change, other than hiring great artists and actors for the season.

 

 

Why Now?

We've done a season one. We want to bring more laughs to your small (or large) screens, and the best time to donate and support the arts is now! We are working on creating content everyday, that will bring smiles.  

 

Other Ways You Can Help

1) SHARE! SHARE! SHARE!

  • Follow us on Instagram
  • Share our Facebook Page
  • Like our videos on Youtube
  • Tell your friends and family about the series! 

2) Sponsor a Craft Services Table (we love food, thank you)

3) Email ihateyoutooseries@gmail.com if you have other ways you'd like to lend a hand :)

4) Re-Watch Season One NOW!

Thank you all!

Cheers,

Kevin Blair and Allie Wessel, Co-Creators

story:
Short Summary

Hi! I'm Abby Denton. I'm a writer, stand-up comic, and total babe. You might know me off the Internet. You might not. I mean, it's fine if you don't. I just write moving, insightful essays about outsider art and culture. It's no big deal if you've never heard of me. I don't mind. I'm fine. I don't know why you're making such a big dePLEASE FOLLOW ME ON TWITTER

I like sitcoms. Who doesn't? Lovely, safe, warm sitcoms, with all the schemes and quips and nonthreatening reflections of the foibles of modern society. Foibles that the cast will survive - as will you, and me, and everyone else. Ahhhh. Nice.

I recently wrote Cyber Cafe, a sitcom in an audio format, and produced a pilot episode, which you can listen to on Soundcloud, below:

https://soundcloud.com/abby-danger-denton/cyber-cafe-episode-1-brains

 

The Story

Cyber Cafe is a sitcom for your ear-holes set in the near future of 20XX. (Eventually people realized things would just keep getting stupider and agreed to stop counting years.) Technology has changed some things - our lead character, Sam, is a brain in a jar - but for the most part people are the same kinds of stupid as they've always been.

Sam works as a coffee sweetener (don't ask) in a cafe, along with Honey, a car crash survivor who got rebuilt to look surprisingly like a Barbie doll, and Emily, a.k.a. D4rk R34p3r, a radical hacktivist who, admittedly, spends most of her time pirating dirty anime. You know the one. Together these workplace compadres face modern and near-future problems like livestreaming their sensory experiences, being forgotten by The Algorithm, and begging strangers for money online (wahey!) You'll love it.

 

The Format

We'll be making 6 episodes of this show, to go online free for you to listen and download and show your friends and pretend it's 2012 and make wacky Youtube Poops. (When I was a student we called Youtube Poop "bricolage.") Episodes will be released one a month, the first of the month, with the finale going out on April 1. Well, maybe April 2 now I see it written out. Don't want people thinking the climax is an April fool's joke.

Episodes are a full half-hour, not like sitcoms these days, with their 11-minute commercial breaks and their baffling respect for the dog's art of improv and their episode scripts you could fit on a napkin. No. We're too good for network television. They asked me, begged me to work for them, but I said no. I'm too principled.

You may have noticed that I said this was in audio. Yes, this is a radioplay, for two big reasons:

1. That's how sitcoms worked in the beginning, back when they all had names like "The Lucky Strikes Cancer-Free Cigarette Hour Starring Jack Benny."
2. I'm broke.

So we're going old-timey and we hope you'll come along.

IMPORTANT DISCLAIMER: When I say we're going old timey, I mean structurally. We're not going to start calling people "pinkos" and refusing to vaccinate our children, like my uncle did when he joined a swing-music revival band. To the best of our abilities, we're leaving the bad stuff in the 40s. Got it?

 

The Team

I've tapped a number of extremely talented compadres for this, including our lead, "Hollywood" Steve Huey, whom you might remember from his cameo in Pirates of the Caribbean: Curse of the Black Pearl, or more likely as the host of Yacht Rock. He is pictured here, reading heretical texts.

Episodes are being directed with the help of Matthew Jay, podcaster and host of the Youtube channel Cartoons101. Music is provided by Star Salzman, responsible for the best Chrono Trigger remix in Internet history!

Also on the team are my comedian buddies, Kenneth "Ken" Cosby and BuzzFeed appearer-on-er Alexandrea Ortiz. Also me myself. Lovely me. Look at me and Ken, just casually hanging out! We're always making faces like this! This is normal to us! We're unstable!!

Over the month of November we'll be announcing a number of special guest performers who'll be helping out with the show, so stay tuned!

 

What We Need & What You Get

We have 6 episodes of this show in the pipeline, and we need some help getting space in a recording studio and feeding the cast, taking a group of starving artists and making them simply "artists," free to pursue whatever new attributive verbs they wish. They may even experiment with adjectives, the dirty little minxes.

Worry not, O ye of little cash: I'm going to be producing this out-of-pocket whether you help me out or not. The problem is, I have those cartoon pockets where you turn them inside out and a little fly buzzes merrily away. Plus, I'm a type 1 diabetic with an electrical pancreas (I've been cyberpunk since age 12) and synthetic insulin isn't cheap. It will take a lot longer, is what I'm saying.

This is not the kind of project that will produce a lovely coffee table book or a cube of pure tungsten. If you want these things, I cannot help you, but you might be able to find them via Bing or AskJeeves. The show will be freely available to you to listen and download no matter what. But we WILL read out your name in the last episode if you donate. Check out our meager rewards tiers if you're into it.

 

The Impact

I can't afford a recording studio. If I produced this out of my apartment, there'd be cars roaring past in every scene, ambulances, fire trucks. I live in Westlake, which might charitably be referred to as Los Angeles's siren district. Without a quiet space to record this show, it would sound like the cast lives and works in a highway overpass, which I admit is an arresting premise, but not the premise we're working with. This is a sitcom about a brain in a jar. Try to keep up.

We need your generous donations to make this happen. Your returns will be meager, but on the bright side, your support will ensure we don't become, say, The Lucky Strikes Cancer-Free Cigarette Hour Featuring Jack Benny. We couldn't afford Benny anyway.

 

Stretch Goals

If we raise $1,100 or more, we'll be able to make a down payment to produce the last episode as a live show in the Los Angeles area in late March, giving you a chance to see the exciting conclusion before anyone else in the world! (We'll also do it in-studio to make sure the recording is good.) If we make enough to produce this, anyone who donates more than $10 will receive a free ticket to the show!
story_txt:
Short Summary
Hi! I'm Abby Denton. I'm a writer, stand-up comic, and total babe. You might know me off the Internet. You might not. I mean, it's fine if you don't. I just write moving, insightful essays about outsider art and culture. It's no big deal if you've never heard of me. I don't mind. I'm fine. I don't know why you're making such a big dePLEASE FOLLOW ME ON TWITTER
I like sitcoms. Who doesn't? Lovely, safe, warm sitcoms, with all the schemes and quips and nonthreatening reflections of the foibles of modern society. Foibles that the cast will survive - as will you, and me, and everyone else. Ahhhh. Nice.
I recently wrote Cyber Cafe, a sitcom in an audio format, and produced a pilot episode, which you can listen to on Soundcloud, below:
https://soundcloud.com/abby-danger-denton/cyber-cafe-episode-1-brains
 
The Story
Cyber Cafe is a sitcom for your ear-holes set in the near future of 20XX. (Eventually people realized things would just keep getting stupider and agreed to stop counting years.) Technology has changed some things - our lead character, Sam, is a brain in a jar - but for the most part people are the same kinds of stupid as they've always been.
Sam works as a coffee sweetener (don't ask) in a cafe, along with Honey, a car crash survivor who got rebuilt to look surprisingly like a Barbie doll, and Emily, a.k.a. D4rk R34p3r, a radical hacktivist who, admittedly, spends most of her time pirating dirty anime. You know the one. Together these workplace compadres face modern and near-future problems like livestreaming their sensory experiences, being forgotten by The Algorithm, and begging strangers for money online (wahey!) You'll love it.
 
The Format
We'll be making 6 episodes of this show, to go online free for you to listen and download and show your friends and pretend it's 2012 and make wacky Youtube Poops. (When I was a student we called Youtube Poop "bricolage.") Episodes will be released one a month, the first of the month, with the finale going out on April 1. Well, maybe April 2 now I see it written out. Don't want people thinking the climax is an April fool's joke.
Episodes are a full half-hour, not like sitcoms these days, with their 11-minute commercial breaks and their baffling respect for the dog's art of improv and their episode scripts you could fit on a napkin. No. We're too good for network television. They asked me, begged me to work for them, but I said no. I'm too principled.
You may have noticed that I said this was in audio. Yes, this is a radioplay, for two big reasons:
1. That's how sitcoms worked in the beginning, back when they all had names like "The Lucky Strikes Cancer-Free Cigarette Hour Starring Jack Benny."2. I'm broke.
So we're going old-timey and we hope you'll come along.
IMPORTANT DISCLAIMER: When I say we're going old timey, I mean structurally. We're not going to start calling people "pinkos" and refusing to vaccinate our children, like my uncle did when he joined a swing-music revival band. To the best of our abilities, we're leaving the bad stuff in the 40s. Got it?
 
The Team
I've tapped a number of extremely talented compadres for this, including our lead, "Hollywood" Steve Huey, whom you might remember from his cameo in Pirates of the Caribbean: Curse of the Black Pearl, or more likely as the host of Yacht Rock. He is pictured here, reading heretical texts.

Episodes are being directed with the help of Matthew Jay, podcaster and host of the Youtube channel Cartoons101. Music is provided by Star Salzman, responsible for the best Chrono Trigger remix in Internet history!
Also on the team are my comedian buddies, Kenneth "Ken" Cosby and BuzzFeed appearer-on-er Alexandrea Ortiz. Also me myself. Lovely me. Look at me and Ken, just casually hanging out! We're always making faces like this! This is normal to us! We're unstable!!

What We Need & What You Get

They may even experiment with adjectives, the dirty little minxes.
Worry not, O ye of little cash: I'm going to be producing this out-of-pocket whether you help me out or not. The problem is, I have those cartoon pockets where you turn them inside out and a little fly buzzes merrily away. Plus, I'm a type 1 diabetic with an electrical pancreas (I've been cyberpunk since age 12) and synthetic insulin isn't cheap. It will take a lot longer, is what I'm saying.

If you want these things, I cannot help you, but you might be able to find them via Bing or AskJeeves. The show will be freely available to you to listen and download no matter what. But we WILL read out your name in the last episode if you donate. Check out our meager rewards tiers if you're into it.
 

The Impact
